questions.question: A superintendent designs a campaign to reduce near-miss events and raise environmental performance. Which purpose of the Company's SMS best justifies this initiative?
options: To meet flag state reporting obligations only
To promote HSQE excellence through leadership and a disciplined, documented system
To minimize document storage costs by digitizing records
To limit legal liability after incidents occur
questions.answer: To promote HSQE excellence through leadership and a disciplined, documented system
questions.explanation: The SMS explicitly aims to promote Health, Safety, Security, Quality, and Environmental excellence via strong leadership and a documented management system.

questions.question: You are auditing the Safety Management System Manual (SMSM). Which set of compliance frameworks should the manual describe according to Company policy?
options: SOLAS and STCW only
ILO Conventions and ISO 14001 only
ISM Code, MLC 2006, and ISO 9001
OCIMF SIRE and TMSA only
questions.answer: ISM Code, MLC 2006, and ISO 9001
questions.explanation: The SMSM's purpose is to describe compliance with the ISM Code, the Maritime Labour Convention (MLC 2006), and ISO 9001 (Quality Management Systems).

questions.question: A department head is updating SMS documentation. Which of the following is LEAST aligned with what the documentation must include?
options: Clear definition of policies, objectives, and targets within the SMS scope
Defined responsibilities, authorities, and interrelations for staff who affect HSQE processes
Documented procedures and appropriate SMS references
Marketing collateral outlining the company's brand identity and color palette
questions.answer: Marketing collateral outlining the company's brand identity and color palette
questions.explanation: System documentation must define scope, responsibilities/authority, and procedures with references'not unrelated marketing materials.

questions.question: During an onboard briefing, the Master asks what event types the crew should report under the SMS. Which answer is most complete?
options: Only nonconformities and incidents
Incidents and personnel accidents; near-misses are optional
Only unsafe acts; unsafe conditions are handled in maintenance
Nonconformities, incidents, personnel accidents, near-misses, unsafe conditions, and unsafe acts
questions.answer: Nonconformities, incidents, personnel accidents, near-misses, unsafe conditions, and unsafe acts
questions.explanation: The SMS requires procedures to report and analyze undesired events including all those listed, ensuring systematic learning and prevention.

questions.question: The technical team wants to shift from reactive fixes to a proactive approach. According to the SMS, which maintenance philosophy should be emphasized?
options: Breakdown maintenance only, to optimize spares usage
Condition monitoring and prevention-based maintenance
Calendar-based replacement of all components every year
Vendor-driven maintenance without internal review
questions.answer: Condition monitoring and prevention-based maintenance
questions.explanation: The SMS calls for condition monitoring and prevention-based maintenance to safeguard the ship's condition.

questions.question: Management asks how the Company evaluates whether the SMS is working effectively. Which combination reflects the required evaluation mechanisms?
options: Quarterly budget reviews and port state MOUs
Internal audits, Management reviews, and Master's reviews
Class annual surveys and PSC inspections only
External financial audits and charterer vettings
questions.answer: Internal audits, Management reviews, and Master's reviews
questions.explanation: System performance and effectiveness are evaluated through internal audits, Management reviews, and Master's reviews per the SMS.

questions.question: The Company plans to establish a new shore office. When determining SMS boundaries and applicability, which factor is most directly relevant?
options: Only the vessel's load line and deadweight
The Company's functions, physical boundaries, and organizational units ashore and onboard
The ship's commercial trading routes
Charter party terms for laytime and demurrage
questions.answer: The Company's functions, physical boundaries, and organizational units ashore and onboard
questions.explanation: SMS boundaries consider the Company's functions and physical/organizational units both ashore and onboard, ensuring coverage as the organization changes.

questions.question: A document controller revises procedures for drawings received from equipment makers. Which control must the SMS include?
options: Optional indexing for external documents, no retention of records
Document and data control including documents of external origin, plus record-keeping
Archiving only electronic documents; paper documents are excluded
Retention of non-referenced documents for historical interest
questions.answer: Document and data control including documents of external origin, plus record-keeping
questions.explanation: The SMS requires document/data control (including external documents) and record-keeping to demonstrate compliance and effective operation.

questions.question: A mixed-nationality crew joins a Company vessel. What is the official communication language between the Company and ships, and the common working language onboard?
options: Greek
English
Spanish
Language decided by the senior officer onboard
questions.answer: English
questions.explanation: The SMS specifies English as the official communication and common working language onboard the ships.

questions.question: A bulk carrier under the Company's management queries whether the SMS applies to it and to shore-based support activities. What is the correct interpretation?
options: The SMS applies to tankers only, not to bulk carriers
The SMS applies only onboard; shore activities are excluded
The SMS applies to all Company activities and the specified ship types, including bulk carriers
The SMS applies only during audits and inspections
questions.answer: The SMS applies to all Company activities and the specified ship types, including bulk carriers
questions.explanation: The SMS applies to all Company activities and the listed ship types; the document explicitly mentions bulk carriers.

questions.question: A superintendent summarizes the Company's mission during an internal briefing. Which statement best represents it?
options: To be the most profitable ship-management company in the region
To set standards for safe and environmentally friendly sea transportation using modern ships and motivated personnel with zero incidents
To dominate the global tanker market through cost reduction
To offer shipping services focused only on environmental innovation
questions.answer: To set standards for safe and environmentally friendly sea transportation using modern ships and motivated personnel with zero incidents
questions.explanation: The mission emphasizes safety, environmental protection, professionalism, and zero incidents, defining the Company's operational purpose.

questions.question: During a Management Review, the team discusses long-term direction. Which vision statement aligns with the Company's declared Vision?
options: To be a leading Company of choice for global sea transportation of cargoes
To maximize quarterly profits for shareholders
To establish the largest fleet in Europe by tonnage
To provide low-cost shipping by reducing crew training
questions.answer: To be a leading Company of choice for global sea transportation of cargoes
questions.explanation: The Vision describes leadership and preference as a global carrier, not fleet size or financial goals alone.

questions.question: A department head designs a workshop on Core Values. Which behavior best demonstrates compliance with those values?
options: Delegating all decisions to subordinates without oversight
Leading by example with persistence, vigilance, and determination
Prioritizing personal convenience over Company policy
Keeping Core Values as posters only without daily application
questions.answer: Leading by example with persistence, vigilance, and determination
questions.explanation: Managers must embody the Core Values through action and leadership by example, not just policy reference.

questions.question: Which description best explains how the Company's SMS responsibilities are distributed?
options: They are limited to shipboard staff only
They extend throughout the organization from the General Manager downwards
They apply solely to the Quality Department
They are delegated entirely to third-party contractors
questions.answer: They extend throughout the organization from the General Manager downwards
questions.explanation: The SMS framework assigns safety and environmental responsibilities to all levels, ensuring accountability company-wide.

questions.question: An officer wants to publish an article about shipboard innovations. What must they do first according to Company Policy?
options: Post freely if content is positive
Obtain prior written approval from the General Manager
Send it to the flag administration for clearance
Submit it anonymously to an online forum
questions.answer: Obtain prior written approval from the General Manager
questions.explanation: Publishing any article concerning Company or ship activities requires prior GM approval under the Articles for Publication policy.

questions.question: A crew member shares vessel operational data with a surveyor. Which boundary defines acceptable disclosure under the Confidential Information policy?
options: Any information that enhances the Company's reputation
Information necessary for the specific operation only
All data except financial information
All details requested by any external party
questions.answer: Information necessary for the specific operation only
questions.explanation: Disclosure is limited to the information required for the specific operational need to protect confidentiality.

questions.question: A shore employee makes an offensive joke to a colleague. Which Company Policy is violated?
options: Environmental Policy
Harassment and Non-Discrimination Policy
Confidential Information Policy
Articles for Publication Policy
questions.answer: Harassment and Non-Discrimination Policy
questions.explanation: The Company explicitly prohibits harassment, bullying, sexual assault, and discrimination of any form.

questions.question: A vessel noticeboard displays the Company's posted policies. What is the purpose of posting them and how often are they reviewed?
options: To meet class requirements only; reviewed every five years
To inform all personnel and ensure they remain valid through annual or as-needed reviews
To satisfy marketing requirements; never reviewed
To remind visiting inspectors; updated quarterly only
questions.answer: To inform all personnel and ensure they remain valid through annual or as-needed reviews
questions.explanation: Policies are displayed in prominent positions and reviewed annually or when necessary to confirm continued validity.

questions.question: A vendor requests access to Company policies. Are these documents publicly available?
options: No, they are strictly internal documents
Yes, they are available to the public, customers, vendors, and suppliers
Only Masters may access them
Only external auditors may view them on request
questions.answer: Yes, they are available to the public, customers, vendors, and suppliers
questions.explanation: The SMS states that Company policies are available to stakeholders including the public, customers, vendors, and suppliers.

questions.question: A manager instructs subordinates to ignore Core Values if operational pressure arises. What does this indicate regarding leadership expectations?
options: It aligns with efficiency over ethics
It contradicts the requirement for Managers to lead by example based on Core Values
It demonstrates proper flexibility in crisis management
It supports delegation under high workload
questions.answer: It contradicts the requirement for Managers to lead by example based on Core Values
questions.explanation: Leaders must consistently uphold Core Values; disregarding them under pressure undermines the Company's cultural foundation.

questions.question: During an internal audit, a reviewer asks what the vertical and horizontal lines in the Company Organization Chart signify. What is the correct interpretation?
options: Vertical lines indicate departmental collaboration, horizontal lines indicate rank order
Vertical lines indicate hierarchical seniority, horizontal lines indicate communication and collaboration
Both indicate equal communication authority across positions
Horizontal lines show seniority, vertical lines show communication channels
questions.answer: Vertical lines indicate hierarchical seniority, horizontal lines indicate communication and collaboration
questions.explanation: In the Company Organization Chart, vertical lines represent rank hierarchy, while horizontal lines denote communication and collaboration among departments.

questions.question: A new crewmember asks how they acknowledge their understanding of duties and responsibilities under the SMS. Which form applies?
options: 002.3.ORG.Inspection Report by Office Personnel
003.3.ORG.Post Management Visit Crew Survey
005.6.1.CREW.Policy Acceptance for seagoing personnel
001.3.ORG.Safety & Environmental Committee Meeting form
questions.answer: 005.6.1.CREW.Policy Acceptance for seagoing personnel
questions.explanation: Seagoing personnel sign Policy Acceptance form 005.6.1.CREW to confirm understanding of their duties and responsibilities.

questions.question: While inspecting a ship, a Port Captain notices crew working without PPE. According to SMS, how should the Port Captain act?
options: Report to the GM after departure only
Lead by example by wearing correct PPE and conduct a safety meeting with the Officers and crew
Allow the work to continue but file a written note later
Stop the operation immediately and leave the vessel
questions.answer: Lead by example by wearing correct PPE and conduct a safety meeting with the Officers and crew
questions.explanation: Technical and Port Captains must lead by example and conduct safety meetings during visits to assess SMS implementation.

questions.question: Following a GM's ship visit, what optional step may the Master take to evaluate the crew's perception of the visit?
options: Request completion of form 003.3.ORG.Post Management Visit Crew Survey
Submit form 002.3.ORG.Inspection Report by Office Personnel
Hold an emergency drill with feedback
Send a verbal summary to the DPA
questions.answer: Request completion of form 003.3.ORG.Post Management Visit Crew Survey
questions.explanation: After management visits, Masters may administer form 003.3.ORG.Post Management Visit Crew Survey to collect feedback from the crew.

questions.question: Which statement best defines the Master's responsibilities under the ship's Safety Organization?
options: Manage safety matters only after incidents occur
Manage all safety-related matters onboard, verify Safety Officer's work, and ensure compliance with policies and procedures
Focus solely on compliance with PSC inspections
Delegate all safety matters to the Chief Officer
questions.answer: Manage all safety-related matters onboard, verify Safety Officer's work, and ensure compliance with policies and procedures
questions.explanation: The Master ensures safe working conditions, oversees safety management, and maintains compliance with the Company's SMS and policies.

questions.question: An Officer assigns a job to a crewmember. According to SMS requirements, what must the Officer confirm before work starts?
options: That the crewmember has completed onboard familiarization only
That the crewmember has the skills for the job, there is a safe work plan, and the workplace is safe
That the crewmember accepts responsibility in writing
That the DPA has been informed
questions.answer: That the crewmember has the skills for the job, there is a safe work plan, and the workplace is safe
questions.explanation: Officers must ensure competence, adequate planning, and a safe workplace before any job starts.

questions.question: A seafarer stops work due to a perceived hazard. What must the Master do before resuming operations?
options: Ensure the hazard is eliminated before work resumes
Document the seafarer's refusal as insubordination
Instruct another person to complete the job immediately
Report the case directly to the DPA without taking action
questions.answer: Ensure the hazard is eliminated before work resumes
questions.explanation: If any employee reports potential risk, the Master must eliminate the hazard before work can continue.

questions.question: Who has the right to request an explanation if they believe their assigned work is disproportionately risky?
options: Only the Safety Officer
Any seafarer, directed to the Safety Officer or a Senior Officer
Only the Master
Only members of the Safety Committee
questions.answer: Any seafarer, directed to the Safety Officer or a Senior Officer
questions.explanation: Each seafarer has the right to question unsafe assignments and request clarification from the Safety or Senior Officer.

questions.question: What is the main function of the ship's Safety Organization?
options: To handle documentation of nonconformities only
To prevent incidents by identifying and addressing hazardous situations
To plan crew rotations and rest hours
To evaluate commercial voyage performance
questions.answer: To prevent incidents by identifying and addressing hazardous situations
questions.explanation: The Safety Organization's primary purpose is preventive'identifying and mitigating hazards before they lead to incidents.

questions.question: When must the Master hold a Safety Committee meeting?
options: At least once per quarter
At least once monthly, after serious incidents, or when otherwise necessary
Only when requested by the DPA
Every six months during ISM audits
questions.answer: At least once monthly, after serious incidents, or when otherwise necessary
questions.explanation: The SMS requires monthly Safety Committee meetings and additional ones after serious incidents or when needed.

questions.question: How many Safety Representatives are required in the Safety Committee, and what is the composition principle?
options: At least 5 elected representatives; composition should not be top-heavy with Senior staff
2 elected representatives; composition primarily senior officers
No limit; members chosen only by the Master
Only permanent members from senior ranks
questions.answer: At least 5 elected representatives; composition should not be top-heavy with Senior staff
questions.explanation: The Committee includes at least 5 elected Safety Representatives and maintains balanced participation, not dominated by senior officers.

questions.question: Where should Safety Committee meetings be held according to SMS?
options: On the Bridge for convenience
In the Master's office
Never on the Bridge or in the ship's office
In any available area without restriction
questions.answer: Never on the Bridge or in the ship's office
questions.explanation: Meetings must not be held on the Bridge or in the ship's office to ensure open participation and avoid operational disturbance.

questions.question: Which actions must follow after Safety Committee meetings?
options: File notes without sharing with crew
Record minutes on form 001.3.ORG.Safety & Environmental Committee Meeting, post copies onboard, and send to DPA
Send verbal updates to managers only
Forward summary to Port State Control
questions.answer: Record minutes on form 001.3.ORG.Safety & Environmental Committee Meeting, post copies onboard, and send to DPA
questions.explanation: Proper documentation ensures transparency'minutes are recorded, posted onboard, and reviewed by the DPA.

questions.question: How soon must the DPA respond to Safety Committee meeting minutes?
options: Within one week of receipt
At the next management review
Only during annual audits
Immediately during a visit
questions.answer: Within one week of receipt
questions.explanation: The DPA must review and respond to Safety Committee minutes within one week and inform Management of important issues.

questions.question: During an internal audit, a reviewer asks about the DPA's principal responsibilities within the SMS. Which statement best summarizes them?
options: Ensure the development and implementation of the SMS and monitor HSQE aspects of Company and fleet operations
Oversee only commercial performance and chartering matters
Supervise vessel classification and certification activities exclusively
Perform voyage optimization and fuel performance monitoring
questions.answer: Ensure the development and implementation of the SMS and monitor HSQE aspects of Company and fleet operations
questions.explanation: The DPA's core role is to ensure that the SMS is developed, implemented, and effectively monitored in all HSQE areas for Company and fleet operations.

questions.question: What additional responsibility does the QMR hold compared to the DPA under the Company's structure?
options: Monitoring quality and customer satisfaction aspects of managed ships' operations
Supervising bunkering and cargo operations
Authorizing all purchasing and crewing transactions
Conducting navigation audits onboard
questions.answer: Monitoring quality and customer satisfaction aspects of managed ships' operations
questions.explanation: While the DPA covers HSQE, the QMR focuses on quality assurance and customer satisfaction monitoring across managed ships.

questions.question: Why is the term 'DPA' used throughout the SMS instead of 'DPA/QMR'?
options: To simplify reference and represent both roles collectively within the management system
Because the QMR position was removed from the Company structure
To comply with flag administration terminology only
Because QMR responsibilities were delegated to Masters
questions.answer: To simplify reference and represent both roles collectively within the management system
questions.explanation: The SMS specifies that 'DPA' is used throughout to refer collectively to DPA and QMR responsibilities for simplicity and consistency.

questions.question: Who assumes responsibility for DPA duties in the DPA's absence?
options: The General Manager
The Deputy DPA
The Safety Officer
The Master of the senior vessel in the fleet
questions.answer: The Deputy DPA
questions.explanation: When the DPA is absent, the Deputy DPA is responsible for carrying out all DPA duties to ensure continuity of oversight.

questions.question: To whom does the DPA report within the Company's organizational hierarchy?
options: Directly to the Flag Administration
To the General Manager
To the Safety Committee
To the Port Captain
questions.answer: To the General Manager
questions.explanation: The DPA reports directly to the General Manager, ensuring a clear line of authority and accountability within the Company.

questions.question: Which combination of qualifications best reflects the Company's expectations for a Master?
options: STCW certification only and cargo handling experience
All STCW certificates for the ship type, ability to lead and motivate crew, assess human performance, and strong English communication skills
Academic degree in marine biology and basic navigation knowledge
Only charter-party and accounting knowledge
questions.answer: All STCW certificates for the ship type, ability to lead and motivate crew, assess human performance, and strong English communication skills
questions.explanation: The Master must meet STCW requirements and demonstrate leadership, communication, and management competence beyond technical certification.

questions.question: Why is the Master described as 'the link between the ship and the Company'?
options: Because the Master reports directly to charterers
Because the Master's decisions and actions onboard are binding on behalf of the Company
Because the Master manages crew payroll and budgets only
Because the Master serves as a communication relay without authority
questions.answer: Because the Master's decisions and actions onboard are binding on behalf of the Company
questions.explanation: The Master represents the Company onboard, and their operational decisions legally and functionally bind the Company.

questions.question: In relation to commercial operations, how is the Master's responsibility toward cargo owners defined?
options: Deliver cargo safely and promptly, avoiding loss, damage, and reputational harm
Ensure minimum demurrage and lowest freight rate
Rely on charterers to coordinate all cargo matters
Delegate cargo delivery entirely to the Chief Officer
questions.answer: Deliver cargo safely and promptly, avoiding loss, damage, and reputational harm
questions.explanation: The Master is responsible toward cargo owners for ensuring safe, timely delivery without incident or reputational impact.

questions.question: A Master encounters conflicting commercial instructions and safety considerations. What must take precedence?
options: Commercial requirements to maintain schedule
Company's business objectives
Safety of human life, the ship, the cargo, and the environment
Charterer's contractual demands
questions.answer: Safety of human life, the ship, the cargo, and the environment
questions.explanation: The Company recognizes the Master's overriding authority to prioritize safety over commercial interests in any conflict.

questions.question: What does the SMS specify about the Master's overriding authority?
options: Decisions must always be pre-approved by the DPA
The Master may take any necessary decision for safety even if it conflicts with the SMS
Overriding authority applies only during drills
The Master must consult charterers before exercising authority
questions.answer: The Master may take any necessary decision for safety even if it conflicts with the SMS
questions.explanation: The SMS explicitly recognizes the Master's right and duty to act independently for safety, even if this contradicts standard procedures.

questions.question: Which communication requirement applies to the Master under the Company's SMS?
options: Only urgent matters need to be reported to the Company
Report any condition affecting flawless operations and consult the Company in case of doubt
Report only after Port State inspections
Communicate through agents only when required
questions.answer: Report any condition affecting flawless operations and consult the Company in case of doubt
questions.explanation: The Master must maintain communication and seek Company assistance whenever operational integrity is in question.

questions.question: Who substitutes the Master in their absence, and to whom does this substitute report?
options: Chief Officer, reporting to the Company's Managers, DPA, and GM
Chief Engineer, reporting to the Port Captain
Designated Person Ashore, reporting to Class
Chief Officer, reporting only to the charterer
questions.answer: Chief Officer, reporting to the Company's Managers, DPA, and GM
questions.explanation: When the Master is absent, the Chief Officer substitutes and reports to the Company's Managers, DPA, and General Manager.

questions.question: The Master reviews new operational instructions and doubts the ship's ability to comply safely. What is the correct action?
options: Attempt to comply and report later
Inform the Company immediately about the doubt before acting
Ignore the instruction and proceed as usual
Wait for the next port to clarify
questions.answer: Inform the Company immediately about the doubt before acting
questions.explanation: If compliance is doubtful, the Master must inform the Company before acting to prevent unsafe outcomes.

questions.question: What is the Company's stance regarding the Master's accountability during office personnel visits?
options: Office presence relieves the Master from responsibility
Master retains full authority and responsibility regardless of office staff presence
Responsibility transfers temporarily to the visiting officer
Authority alternates based on rank
questions.answer: Master retains full authority and responsibility regardless of office staff presence
questions.explanation: Even when office staff are onboard, the Master remains fully responsible for the ship's safe and efficient operation.

questions.question: Which of the following demonstrates a critical skill listed among the Master's qualifications?
options: Ability to create company marketing materials
Ability to assess human performance and motivate crew
Familiarity with insurance underwriting
Knowledge of naval architecture design codes
questions.answer: Ability to assess human performance and motivate crew
questions.explanation: The SMS requires the Master to evaluate human performance and inspire effective teamwork onboard.

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the Company's crew resource policy as described in this chapter?
options: To employ the least expensive crew available
To select, recruit, and administer experienced, qualified, medically fit, and competent seafarers through a controlled process
To delegate all crew management to third-party agencies
To focus recruitment only on newly graduated cadets
questions.answer: To select, recruit, and administer experienced, qualified, medically fit, and competent seafarers through a controlled process
questions.explanation: The Company's policy establishes systematic controls to ensure that all seafarers are competent, qualified, and fit for service.

questions.question: How does the Company verify that seafarers meet the standards of competence and performance?
options: By conducting random interviews at ports
Through an appraisal system verifying competence and qualification
By relying solely on manning agencies' endorsements
By accepting self-declarations from the crew
questions.answer: Through an appraisal system verifying competence and qualification
questions.explanation: A structured appraisal system ensures that each seafarer's competence and qualifications are evaluated and maintained.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key focus of the Company's approach to human resources?
options: Retaining and developing people in key roles while promoting seafarers' continuity and motivation
Replacing crew frequently to minimize cost
Outsourcing all shipboard training programs
Focusing only on shore staff development
questions.answer: Retaining and developing people in key roles while promoting seafarers' continuity and motivation
questions.explanation: The Company emphasizes stability, motivation, and development of key personnel as part of its proactive HR policy.

questions.question: What is the Company's policy regarding the employment of persons under 18 years old onboard?
options: Permitted with parental consent
Prohibited entirely
Allowed for cadet training voyages only
Permitted under special flag dispensation
questions.answer: Prohibited entirely
questions.explanation: Employment or work onboard of any person under 18 years of age is explicitly prohibited.

questions.question: Before dismissing a seafarer for poor performance, what must the Master ensure?
options: That a warning and an opportunity to improve have been given
That the DPA has issued a dismissal order
That all colleagues agree with the dismissal
That the ship's Safety Committee approves
questions.answer: That a warning and an opportunity to improve have been given
questions.explanation: Disciplinary action must follow fair process'warning, chance to improve, and objective documentation per labor agreements.

questions.question: What type of wording must be avoided in documentation concerning disciplinary actions?
options: Objective and factual language
Subjective or generalized wording such as 'malicious' or 'on several occasions'
References to specific incidents
Direct quotations from witnesses
questions.answer: Subjective or generalized wording such as 'malicious' or 'on several occasions'
questions.explanation: The SMS cautions against subjective or vague wording to maintain fairness and factual accuracy in records.

questions.question: How does the Company address acts of discrimination, harassment, bullying, sexual assault, or sexual harassment?
options: By treating them as minor disciplinary matters
By enforcing a zero-tolerance policy and encouraging immediate reporting and investigation
By delegating resolution entirely to the ship's Master
By handling cases informally without documentation
questions.answer: By enforcing a zero-tolerance policy and encouraging immediate reporting and investigation
questions.explanation: The Company maintains zero tolerance and promotes reporting, investigation, and preventive onboard programs.

questions.question: Who serves as the first point of reference for a seafarer wishing to make a harassment or discrimination complaint?
options: Designated Person Ashore (DPA)
Safety Officer
Master
Crew Representative
questions.answer: Master
questions.explanation: The Master is the initial contact for any seafarer raising a complaint unless the Master is personally involved.

questions.question: If the Master is involved in a harassment or bullying case, who becomes the contact point for the affected seafarer?
options: The Port Captain
The Designated Person Ashore (DPA)
The Flag Administration
The Shipowner directly
questions.answer: The Designated Person Ashore (DPA)
questions.explanation: When the Master is implicated, the DPA acts as the contact point to ensure impartial handling of the complaint.

questions.question: What informal option is available to a victim when resolving a harassment or bullying complaint?
options: Public hearing at the Safety Committee
Written reprimand without discussion
An informal meeting where the perpetrator may apologize and commit not to repeat the behavior
Immediate dismissal of the perpetrator without review
questions.answer: An informal meeting where the perpetrator may apologize and commit not to repeat the behavior
questions.explanation: The SMS allows informal resolution if the victim agrees, enabling discussion, apology, and commitment to behavioral change.

questions.question: What is the overall objective of the Company's policy for managing shore personnel?
options: To ensure shore staff are selected, appointed, and administered as experienced, qualified, and competent professionals
To reduce the number of shore staff to cut operating expenses
To assign temporary staff to all shore positions to increase flexibility
To centralize all HR decisions under the DPA only
questions.answer: To ensure shore staff are selected, appointed, and administered as experienced, qualified, and competent professionals
questions.explanation: The Company applies controls to ensure shore personnel are capable, qualified, and effectively managed to support safe and efficient ship management.

questions.question: Why does the Company emphasize employing sufficient shore personnel?
options: To provide full supervision of managed ships and ensure efficient implementation of HSQE processes
To handle external marketing campaigns
To reduce reliance on third-party technical service providers
To comply solely with flag administration manning levels
questions.answer: To provide full supervision of managed ships and ensure efficient implementation of HSQE processes
questions.explanation: Adequate shore staffing ensures both operational control and compliance with HSQE standards across managed vessels.

questions.question: How does the Company verify the authenticity of shore employees' qualifications and records?
options: By assuming that all certificates issued by recognized institutions are valid
By checking that declared qualifications are valid, genuine, and that pre-employment records are accurate
By delegating verification entirely to recruitment agencies
By requesting self-declarations only
questions.answer: By checking that declared qualifications are valid, genuine, and that pre-employment records are accurate
questions.explanation: The Company verifies both documentation and background details to ensure all shore employees meet required standards.

questions.question: What method is used to assess and support the continued competence of shore personnel?
options: A peer voting system within departments
An appraisal system verifying qualifications and facilitating further development
Annual written exams without review
Outsourcing evaluations to external consultants only
questions.answer: An appraisal system verifying qualifications and facilitating further development
questions.explanation: Regular appraisals help confirm competence and identify development needs for continuous improvement.

questions.question: How does the Company retain and enhance the skills of key shore personnel such as Managers and Superintendents?
options: Through initial on-the-job refresher training and participation in industry seminars and forums
By offering extended shore leave periods
By rotating them between unrelated departments
By delegating training responsibilities entirely to ship crews
questions.answer: Through initial on-the-job refresher training and participation in industry seminars and forums
questions.explanation: Continuous professional development ensures key shore staff maintain current knowledge and skills relevant to the maritime industry.

questions.question: What principle underpins the Company's policy on equal opportunities and motivation for shore staff?
options: Meritocracy, providing advancement based on ability and contribution
Seniority, regardless of performance
Preference for internal recommendations only
Rotation policy based on availability
questions.answer: Meritocracy, providing advancement based on ability and contribution
questions.explanation: The Company promotes merit-based advancement, fairness, and equal opportunities to encourage motivation and commitment.

questions.question: How does the Company maintain commitment and motivation among shore personnel?
options: By encouraging job satisfaction and personal development
By offering bonuses based solely on company profit
By implementing rigid schedules without feedback mechanisms
By outsourcing HR management
questions.answer: By encouraging job satisfaction and personal development
questions.explanation: The SMS emphasizes engagement and satisfaction as drivers of motivation and performance among shore employees.

questions.question: What additional function does the Company's personnel management system serve beyond compliance?
options: It supports long-term retention and development of people in key roles
It focuses exclusively on recruitment targets
It limits training opportunities to control costs
It centralizes payroll operations
questions.answer: It supports long-term retention and development of people in key roles
questions.explanation: The personnel system is designed not only for compliance but also to sustain continuity and growth in essential positions.

questions.question: What is the main objective of the Maritime Labour Convention (MLC) 2006 as applied within the Company's SMS?
options: To increase port state inspection frequency for ships
To safeguard seafarers' wellbeing and ensure their health and safety in all aspects of onboard life and work
To define shipboard operational efficiency standards
To regulate only working hours and rest periods of seafarers
questions.answer: To safeguard seafarers' wellbeing and ensure their health and safety in all aspects of onboard life and work
questions.explanation: The MLC's purpose is to protect seafarers' wellbeing, health, and safety across all areas of living and working conditions onboard.

questions.question: How does the MLC contribute to global consistency in the shipping industry?
options: By creating national labor regulations for each flag state
By establishing an international instrument of control and common standards for seafaring issues
By focusing only on shipowners' liability clauses
By promoting regional agreements for seafarer unions
questions.answer: By establishing an international instrument of control and common standards for seafaring issues
questions.explanation: The MLC serves as a global framework aligning seafarer welfare standards across nations and stakeholders.

questions.question: What is one of the main benefits of implementing MLC requirements onboard?
options: Reduced port formalities
Prevention of substandard working and living conditions while ensuring a safe environment for personnel
Higher insurance premiums for shipowners
Increased flexibility in manning requirements
questions.answer: Prevention of substandard working and living conditions while ensuring a safe environment for personnel
questions.explanation: The MLC prevents poor standards and enhances living and working conditions to safeguard crew welfare.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the structure of the MLC?
options: A single uniform code of conduct for seafarers
Three related parts: Articles, Regulations, and the Code
Two main parts: Technical Rules and Compliance Guidance
Separate regional conventions per maritime zone
questions.answer: Three related parts: Articles, Regulations, and the Code
questions.explanation: The MLC consists of Articles, Regulations, and the Code'each addressing different aspects of rights, obligations, and enforcement.

questions.question: What is the purpose of including the 16 general areas in the Declaration of Maritime Labour Compliance (DMLC)?
options: To serve as a checklist ensuring all MLC requirements are implemented and verified
To establish the ship's crew list and manning certificate
To define national reporting obligations for shipowners
To replace the ISM Code certification
questions.answer: To serve as a checklist ensuring all MLC requirements are implemented and verified
questions.explanation: The 16 general areas ensure full compliance and documentation of MLC provisions within the ship's DMLC.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the 16 general areas that must be addressed in the DMLC?
options: Medical certification
Payment of wages
Cargo operations and stowage planning
Health and safety and accident prevention
questions.answer: Cargo operations and stowage planning
questions.explanation: The DMLC covers welfare, safety, and employment conditions'not operational cargo management.

questions.question: What does the MLC seek to achieve regarding the treatment of seafarers worldwide?
options: A competitive advantage for lower-wage nations
Fair and equal treatment of all seafarers through a global level playing field
National preference for domestic seafarers
Freedom for shipowners to set individual working terms
questions.answer: Fair and equal treatment of all seafarers through a global level playing field
questions.explanation: By setting common minimum standards, the MLC ensures fairness and prevents exploitation or competitive undercutting of seafarers' conditions.

questions.question: How does the MLC promote the interests of seafarers in a changing industry?
options: By supporting innovations within MLC implementation and enhancing welfare systems
By limiting seafarer mobility between flags
By discouraging ship automation and modernization
By transferring welfare responsibilities to port states
questions.answer: By supporting innovations within MLC implementation and enhancing welfare systems
questions.explanation: The MLC evolves with industry advancements while keeping seafarer welfare as its focus.

questions.question: How are the core principles and obligations of the Maritime Labour Convention (MLC) 2006 structured?
options: They are detailed only in the Code Part B guidelines
They are set out in the Articles and Regulations, with implementation details in the Code
They are contained solely within the Declaration of Maritime Labour Compliance (DMLC)
They are published separately by each flag administration
questions.answer: They are set out in the Articles and Regulations, with implementation details in the Code
questions.explanation: The Articles and Regulations define core rights and obligations, while the Code provides the practical implementation standards.

questions.question: Which two parts make up the MLC Code, and what is the main difference between them?
options: Part A (mandatory standards) and Part B (non-mandatory guidelines)
Part 1 (national) and Part 2 (international)
Part A (administrative) and Part B (operational)
Part I (optional provisions) and Part II (recommended practices)
questions.answer: Part A (mandatory standards) and Part B (non-mandatory guidelines)
questions.explanation: The Code consists of mandatory standards (Part A) and guidance (Part B), supporting consistent MLC implementation.

questions.question: What are the five Titles under which the MLC Regulations and Code are organized?
options: Title 1: Minimum requirements; Title 2: Conditions of employment; Title 3: Accommodation, recreation, food and catering; Title 4: Health protection, medical care, welfare and social security; Title 5: Compliance and enforcement
Title 1: Maritime safety; Title 2: Pollution prevention; Title 3: Crew welfare; Title 4: Insurance; Title 5: Certification
Title 1: Management; Title 2: HR; Title 3: Technical; Title 4: Operational; Title 5: Audit
Title 1: Recruitment; Title 2: Pay; Title 3: Training; Title 4: Welfare; Title 5: Environment
questions.answer: Title 1: Minimum requirements; Title 2: Conditions of employment; Title 3: Accommodation, recreation, food and catering; Title 4: Health protection, medical care, welfare and social security; Title 5: Compliance and enforcement
questions.explanation: These five Titles cover all essential areas of seafarers' working and living conditions and the mechanisms for enforcement.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the organization of the MLC's Regulations and Code under the Titles?
options: Each Title focuses on unrelated administrative issues
Each Title groups provisions around a specific right, principle, or enforcement measure
Titles are chronological records of the MLC's revision history
Titles represent national annexes of the MLC
questions.answer: Each Title groups provisions around a specific right, principle, or enforcement measure
questions.explanation: Each MLC Title focuses on a thematic area, ensuring comprehensive coverage of seafarer rights and enforcement mechanisms.

questions.question: What are the two important terms introduced in this Chapter that relate to MLC compliance documentation?
options: ISM Manual and Safety Management Certificate
Declaration of Maritime Labour Compliance (DMLC) and Maritime Labour Certificate
Ship Safety Equipment Certificate and DOC
Port State Control Report and Class Endorsement
questions.answer: Declaration of Maritime Labour Compliance (DMLC) and Maritime Labour Certificate
questions.explanation: These two documents demonstrate compliance with MLC requirements'the DMLC details implementation, and the MLC Certificate verifies compliance.

questions.question: What is the function of the Declaration of Maritime Labour Compliance (DMLC) under the MLC framework?
options: To record cargo manifest and stability data
To outline how the ship and Company comply with each applicable MLC requirement
To provide a list of company policies unrelated to crew welfare
To serve as the ship's certificate of registry
questions.answer: To outline how the ship and Company comply with each applicable MLC requirement
questions.explanation: The DMLC serves as the compliance roadmap, showing how MLC requirements are implemented by the Company and verified by authorities.

questions.question: What is the overarching principle governing the conduct of all shipboard operations under the Company's SMS?
options: To prioritize speed and commercial efficiency above all else
To conduct all operations safely, efficiently, and in compliance with Company procedures, laws, and industry best practices
To follow only flag state regulations regardless of Company policies
To allow operational discretion without procedural oversight
questions.answer: To conduct all operations safely, efficiently, and in compliance with Company procedures, laws, and industry best practices

questions.question: What is the purpose of identifying shipboard operations and their associated risks within the SMS?

To define risk management controls and establish relevant safety procedures
To delegate risk ownership to charterers
To meet ISO audit formalities only

questions.explanation: The Company identifies shipboard activities and risks to apply proper control measures and ensure safe operations.

questions.question: Which system is used to authorize and control high-risk tasks on board?

The Crew Performance Review System
The Voyage Planning System
The Port State Safety Checklist
questions.answer: The Company's 'Permit to Work System'

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Company's 'Permit to Work System'?
options: To manage crew leave schedules
To assess, authorize, and monitor potentially hazardous work under controlled conditions
To validate voyage passage plans
To document ship maintenance logs
questions.answer: To assess, authorize, and monitor potentially hazardous work under controlled conditions
questions.explanation: The Permit to Work system ensures work does not proceed under unsafe conditions and that hazards are identified and controlled.

questions.question: What is included in the Company's procedures for developing or amending plans and instructions for operations?
options: Random review by Masters
Systematic planning, development, and record-keeping for both shore and shipboard operations
Ad hoc approval by superintendents without documentation
Delegation entirely to external consultants

questions.explanation: The SMS requires that all new or amended operational procedures are developed systematically and properly documented.

questions.question: Which safety principle applies to the design of workplace procedures and work organization?
options: Eliminate or reduce occupational health and safety risks at their source
Assign complex tasks to less experienced personnel for learning purposes
Focus primarily on minimizing operational costs
Adapt procedures only after incidents occur
questions.answer: Eliminate or reduce occupational health and safety risks at their source
questions.explanation: The SMS directs that workplace procedures and organization should remove or minimize OH&S risks directly at the source.

questions.question: What is the Master's authority concerning SMS procedures in exceptional situations?

The Master may take any steps necessary for safety and environmental protection even if they conflict with the SMS
The Master's authority is limited to normal operational conditions
The DPA must pre-approve any deviation from the SMS before action

questions.explanation: The SMS explicitly states that the Master retains overriding authority to act independently in emergencies or exceptional cases.

questions.question: Why does the SMS emphasize maintaining suitable equipment and monitoring devices onboard?
options: To comply with PSC inspection expectations only
To ensure effective monitoring, measurement, and validation of processes critical to safety and environmental protection
To reduce equipment redundancy
To simplify shipboard record-keeping
questions.answer: To ensure effective monitoring, measurement, and validation of processes critical to safety and environmental protection
questions.explanation: Proper equipment and monitoring tools ensure operational processes meet safety and environmental standards.

questions.question: How does the Company ensure continuous improvement in its operational safety management?

By allowing each ship to develop its own independent procedures
By limiting updates to major incidents only
By removing records once audits are completed
questions.answer: By maintaining approved processes, validation, and documented evidence of compliance
questions.explanation: Continuous improvement relies on process validation, proper documentation, and evidence of compliance with safety standards.

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the Company's Navigation Policy?

To ensure the safety of the crew, ship, cargo, and environment through proper navigation procedures
To follow commercial priorities established by charterers
To delegate navigation decisions entirely to the Officer of the Watch
questions.answer: To ensure the safety of the crew, ship, cargo, and environment through proper navigation procedures
questions.explanation: The policy prioritizes safety and environmental protection above all operational or commercial concerns.

questions.question: What concept underlies the Company's navigation approach to prevent human error?
options: Bridge Resource Management (BRM)
Bridge Team Management (BTM)
Navigation Safety System (NSS)
Electronic Chart Display and Information System (ECDIS)

questions.question: What are all deck officers required to know under the Navigation Policy?

The Company's navigation procedures, COLREGS, their duties, navigational equipment, and the ship's maneuvering capabilities
Only how to operate ECDIS and radar
The ship's commercial routes and cargo details
questions.answer: The Company's navigation procedures, COLREGS, their duties, navigational equipment, and the ship's maneuvering capabilities
questions.explanation: All officers must be familiar with Company navigation procedures, COLREGS, duties, and equipment operation to ensure safety.

questions.question: How are navigational charts and publications kept up to date onboard?
options: Officers manually sketch chart corrections
The designated officer updates ENCs and publications provided by contracted chart agents
Updates are made only when Port State Control requests it
The Master sends updates to agents after each voyage
questions.answer: The designated officer updates ENCs and publications provided by contracted chart agents
questions.explanation: The SMS requires that contracted chart agents supply current ENCs and the designated officer ensures all updates are applied.

questions.question: What must the navigation officer do before every voyage?
options: Obtain the Master's approval of the prepared passage plan
Submit the plan to the charterer for approval
Wait for the DPA's permission before sailing
Request weather routing advice from insurers
questions.answer: Obtain the Master's approval of the prepared passage plan
questions.explanation: The navigation officer must prepare and submit the passage plan for the Master's review and approval before departure.

questions.question: How should the voyage be conducted once the passage plan is approved?
options: Freely adjusted without documentation
Adhered to as planned, with modifications only for weather, traffic, or ship condition changes
Modified at the discretion of the OOW without Master consultation
Followed strictly without any possible changes
questions.answer: Adhered to as planned, with modifications only for weather, traffic, or ship condition changes
questions.explanation: The voyage must follow the approved plan, allowing only necessary adjustments for safety and operational conditions.

questions.question: What is the Master's overarching responsibility under the Navigation Policy?
options: To delegate navigation entirely to officers
To ensure the ship's safe navigation in full compliance with laws, regulations, and Company procedures
To follow charterers' routing instructions as a priority
To monitor only external communications with agents
questions.answer: To ensure the ship's safe navigation in full compliance with laws, regulations, and Company procedures
questions.explanation: The Master holds ultimate responsibility for safe navigation and must ensure all navigational practices align with regulatory and Company standards.

questions.question: What principle guides all decisions during navigation according to the Company's policy?
options: Commercial efficiency takes priority over safety
Safety of life and the ship always takes precedence over other considerations
Compliance with charterer instructions is the top priority
Navigational decisions are shared equally among the bridge team
questions.answer: Safety of life and the ship always takes precedence over other considerations
questions.explanation: The policy clearly establishes that safety outweighs all commercial or operational pressures.

questions.question: What does the policy state regarding individual responsibility during navigation?
options: Responsibility rests solely with the Master
Every Master, Officer, and rating must apply knowledge and sound judgment at all times
Only the Officer of the Watch is accountable
Responsibility shifts to the DPA during difficult conditions
questions.answer: Every Master, Officer, and rating must apply knowledge and sound judgment at all times
questions.explanation: No procedure relieves any individual from exercising sound professional judgment to maintain navigational safety.

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the Company's Mooring and Anchoring Policy?
options: To ensure ships moor efficiently to minimize port time
To equip ships with safe mooring systems that comply with industry standards and Company procedures
To allow each ship to determine its own mooring methods based on experience
To reduce the number of mooring lines required for each operation
questions.answer: To equip ships with safe mooring systems that comply with industry standards and Company procedures
questions.explanation: The policy ensures that all ships are properly equipped and follow established safety and procedural standards during mooring and anchoring operations.

questions.question: According to the policy, mooring arrangements must comply with which external criteria in addition to Company procedures?

Flag State manning levels
Charter party clauses
Port agent recommendations
questions.answer: Terminal safety criteria
questions.explanation: The policy mandates compliance with safety requirements issued by visiting terminals alongside Company procedures and industry standards.

questions.question: How does the Company ensure continued compliance with new regulations on mooring equipment and lines?

By enforcing in-service inspection and maintenance regimes for mooring systems
By relying solely on shipboard self-assessments
By requesting reports from terminal operators
questions.answer: By enforcing in-service inspection and maintenance regimes for mooring systems
questions.explanation: The Company maintains regulatory compliance through structured inspection and maintenance programs for mooring gear and lines.

questions.question: What is the Company's approach toward learning and improvement in mooring practices?

Conduct reviews of mooring practices and apply lessons learned from incidents and near misses
Focus on equipment replacement rather than review processes
Allow each vessel to decide if reviews are necessary

questions.question: Which action ensures organizational awareness and risk mitigation in mooring system management?
options: Periodic verification of cargo manifold pressure limits
Reviewing system design, assessing risks, and implementing mitigation measures
Reducing the number of lines used during mooring
Allowing ad hoc modifications to deck fittings
questions.answer: Reviewing system design, assessing risks, and implementing mitigation measures
questions.explanation: The Company mandates structured review, documentation, and risk control for all mooring systems to maintain safety integrity.

questions.question: How does the Company promote safety in new building and second-hand tonnage projects?
options: By applying latest industry standards for new builds and planning upgrades for older vessels
By focusing exclusively on new ship deliveries
By limiting compliance to existing fleet only
By delegating safety design to shipyards without review
questions.answer: By applying latest industry standards for new builds and planning upgrades for older vessels
questions.explanation: The Company ensures new vessels meet modern safety design standards and develops upgrade timelines for second-hand ships.

questions.question: Which personnel are directly responsible for ensuring safe mooring and anchoring operations onboard?
options: Port agents and terminal representatives
Master, Chief Officer, and Deck Officers in charge
Chief Engineer and Engine Room staff
Designated Person Ashore only

questions.question: What must Masters and Deck Officers ensure regarding mooring equipment certification?

That all certificates for mooring equipment and lines are available onboard
That certificates are renewed only when requested by port authorities
That expired certificates are retained for historical reference
questions.answer: That all certificates for mooring equipment and lines are available onboard
questions.explanation: The SMS requires current certificates for all mooring equipment, lines, and shackles to be maintained and accessible onboard.

questions.question: Why are mooring and anchoring operations considered particularly hazardous?
options: Because of their routine nature leading to complacency
Because they involve heavy loads under tension, moving equipment, and high risk of injury or failure
Because they require minimal supervision
Because they only depend on environmental conditions
questions.answer: Because they involve heavy loads under tension, moving equipment, and high risk of injury or failure
questions.explanation: Mooring and anchoring operations are inherently dangerous due to dynamic loads, equipment strain, and proximity to moving lines.

questions.question: What is the fundamental principle governing all engineering operations onboard according to the Company's policy?
options: To conduct engineering tasks quickly to save fuel
To carry out all engineering operations safely, efficiently, and in strict conformance with laws, regulations, and good engineering practices
To perform maintenance only during port stays
To prioritize cost savings over technical standards
questions.answer: To carry out all engineering operations safely, efficiently, and in strict conformance with laws, regulations, and good engineering practices
questions.explanation: Engineering operations must always align with legal, regulatory, and best-practice standards to ensure safety and efficiency.

The equipment maker's instructions
The charterer's representative
The Class surveyor's verbal guidance

questions.explanation: Following manufacturer instructions ensures maintenance and operation align with design specifications and safety standards.

questions.question: What must engineering personnel ensure when performing tasks or supervising others?

That only senior officers are involved in maintenance
That all work is delegated to external contractors
That tasks are completed as quickly as possible regardless of risk

questions.explanation: Compliance with COSWP guidance minimizes hazards and ensures safe working practices in the Engine Room.

To ensure even wear, reliability, and operational readiness of both units
To maintain symmetry in the ship's layout
To meet environmental reporting obligations

Testing of automatic changeover devices during startup and shutdown, and system shutdowns at regular intervals
Hull integrity ultrasonic checks
Main engine cylinder pressure verification

questions.question: What verification responsibility does the Chief Engineer have during their contract?

To review the Master's Safety Management audit
To conduct monthly deck maintenance reports
To oversee shipboard financial accounts
questions.answer: To confirm that Engine Room procedures and standards are properly maintained as per Chapter 12 and form 014.12.AUD.C/E's Verification Assessment
questions.explanation: The Chief Engineer must verify compliance with Company engineering standards and report findings through the designated audit form.

questions.question: What is the primary reason for maintaining and frequently checking all machinery and equipment?

To ensure proper operation and prevent breakdowns or unsafe conditions
To satisfy oil major requirements only
To maintain the vessel's aesthetic condition

To focus solely on administrative reporting
To review only environmental documentation

questions.question: What is the main purpose of the Company's procedures for cargo handling operations?

To simplify paperwork for port agents

questions.question: Why is it important to have structured procedures for cargo operations onboard?

Because they eliminate the requirement for cargo plans

questions.explanation: Systematic cargo handling procedures are vital for maintaining safety, avoiding pollution, and meeting ISM and regulatory compliance.

Cargo interests are responsible for onboard safety
Crew participation should be minimized to avoid liability

questions.question: What is the expected outcome of applying Company cargo handling procedures correctly?

Delegation of all cargo operations to terminal staff

questions.answer: By documenting and reviewing cargo handling experiences to improve future performance and training

questions.question: What is the overarching purpose of the Company's environmental protection policy described in this chapter?

To guarantee compliance with MARPOL, Flag Administration regulations, and applicable industry standards
To promote cost efficiency by reducing equipment usage
To delegate environmental responsibilities to shore management only

questions.explanation: The Company's ships must operate in compliance with MARPOL, Flag, and other applicable regulatory and industry environmental standards.

questions.question: According to this chapter, how does the Company manage the interaction between shipboard activities and the environment?

By setting minimum SMS requirements to ensure compliance with applicable environmental rules and Company standards
By applying ad-hoc measures during inspections
By delegating full responsibility to classification societies

questions.explanation: The Company's SMS provides structured controls to manage shipboard environmental interactions and maintain compliance.

Noise pollution exclusively

To reduce fuel costs through stricter internal controls

To comply only with charterer preferences

To encourage controlled recreational drinking during rest hours

questions.explanation: The D&A policy ensures that no one onboard is impaired by drugs or alcohol, maintaining safety and compliance.

To Company shore staff only

questions.question: When is the consumption of any alcohol strictly prohibited regardless of the 2-day allowance?

Wait until the next shift to confirm
Report only after completion of voyage

questions.question: What disciplinary action may result from using or possessing illegal drugs or substances onboard?

Verbal reprimand

In the ship's bonded store freely accessible to all
In the messroom refrigerator

questions.question: What must crew and visitors avoid storing onboard under any circumstances?
